document.masterDocTitle: Notes on the genus Astenus Dejean, 1833 in the Mediterranean and adjacent regions. A new species from Turkey, seven new synonyms, and additional records (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Paederinae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 55–66.
Astenus thoracicus ( Baudi di Selve, 1857 )
, intraspecific variation of aedeagus in lateral view: 55) Turkey, western Anatolia; 56) Turkey, northern Anatolia; 57) Turkey, southwestern Anatolia; 58) Turkey, central Anatolia; 59) Turkey, southeastern Anatolia; 60) Georgia, Sukhum; 61) Russia, Krasnodar; 62) Israel, Galilée; 63) Syria; 64) Greece; 65) Bulgaria; 66) Cyprus Scale bars: 55–66) 0.2 mm.

Distribution:
A. thoracicus
is a widespread species in the Eastern Mediterranean and adjacent regions. It is distributed in Georgia , Azerbaijan , Greece , Cyprus , Bulgaria , Italy , Canary Islands, Iran , Syria , Israel , Uzbekistan and Turkey . The records from Lebanon and Russia are reported for the first time.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 67–74. Details of
Astenus jordanicus Coiffait, 1981
; 67) habitus, paratype; 68) forebody, paratype; 69) paratype male sternite VII; 70) paratype male sternite VIII; 71) paratype aedeagus, lateral view; 72) paratype aedeagus, ventral view; 73) Allotype labels; 74) Paratype labels. Scale bars, 67–68) 0.5 mm, 69–72) 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments: Coiffait (1981) described
A. jordanicus
based on a male ( holotype ) from Zerkatal b. Romana ( Zarka Valley near Rumana), four males and three females ( paratypes ) from Jordan Valley, Wadi Farra in Jordan . According to Coiffait (1981) , type series of the species were deposited in the author`s collection in MNHNP and HNHM. I visited both museums, but I could not find any type specimen of
A. jordanicus in HNHM. An Allotype
, one male and one female ( paratypes ) of
A. jordanicus
were studied in the collection of H. Coiffait in MNHNP. Coiffait (1981) did not mention the differences of this species from other
Astenus
species in the original description of
A. jordanicus .

A. thoracicus
is probably the most common species of the genus in the East Mediterranean. Based on the original description of
A. jordanicus
( Figs. 67–74 ) and the illustrations of the aedeagus in Coiffait (1981 : Figs. 1 G–H), the external morphology and aedeagal characters are found within the range of intraspecific variation of A. thoracicus ( Figs. 55–66 ). This species is here placed in the synonymy of
A. thoracicus .
